## {#ln-blank-2 data-menu-title="Natural Logs"}

[Natural logarithms]{.slide-title}

<hr>

If $y>0$, then **$\ln(x)$ is the exponent you need to raise $e$ to in order to get $y$.**

This means:

$$
\begin{align}
\ln(e^x) &= x \\
e^{\ln(y)} &= y
\end{align}
$$

In other words, $\ln(x)$ is the inverse of the exponential function $e^x$. 

<br>

**Examples**

- $\ln(e^3)$

- $\ln(\frac{1}{e})$

- $\ln(1)$

- $\ln(0)$ 

- $\ln(-7)$ 


<!----------------------------------------------------->
## {#ln data-menu-title="Natural Logs"}

[Natural logarithms]{.slide-title}

<hr>

If $y>0$, then **$\ln(x)$ is the exponent you need to raise $e$ to in order to get $y$.**

This means:

$$
\begin{align}
\ln(e^x) &= x \\
e^{\ln(y)} &= y
\end{align}
$$

In other words, $\ln(x)$ is the inverse of the exponential function $e^x$. 

<br>

**Examples**

- $\ln(e^3) = 3$ because 3 is the power of $e$ needed to get $e^3$.

- $\ln(\frac{1}{e}) = \ln(e^{-1}) = -1$

- $\ln(1) = 0$ because 0 is the exponent we need to raise $e$ to to get 1

- $\ln(0)$ does not exist, because there's no number we can raise $e$ to to get 0

- $\ln(-7)$ does not exist, because $e$ to any number always be positive

## {#ln-ex data-menu-title="Natural Logs"}

[Using logarithms to solve equations]{.slide-title}

<hr>
✏️ [Solve for $t$ in the equation $Pe^{rt} = A$. ]{style="color:green;"}

$$
\begin{align}
Pe^{rt} &= A \\
e^{rt} & = \frac{A}{P} \\
rt &= \ln\left(\frac{A}{P}\right) \\
t &= \frac{\ln(A)-\ln(P)}{r}
\end{align}
$$

## {#ln-derv-ex data-menu-title="Natural Log"}

[Example]{.slide-title}

<hr>

✏️ [Find the derivative of $y=\ln(x^2)$. ]{style="color:green;"}

A solution with $u$-substitution.

$$
\begin{align}
y=\ln(u)& &u=x^2\\
\frac{dy}{du}&=\frac{1}{u} &\frac{du}{dx}=2x \\
\frac{dy}{du}\frac{du}{dx}&=\frac{2x}{u} &\text{By Chain Rule}\\
\frac{dy}{dx}&=\frac{2x}{x^2}\\
\frac{dy}{dx}&=\frac{2}{x}\\
\end{align}
$$

## {#ta-1 data-menu-title="Team Assessment"}

1) Solve these equations

$$
\begin{align}
\text{A)  }5+\ln(3x)=7  &  &\text{B) } e^{5x-0.2}=10
\end{align}
$$

<br>

. . .

2) Find the derivative of $f(x)=x \ln x.$

<br>

. . .

3) The popuplation $P(t)$ of an invasive plant species in a wetland (in thousands of individuals) grows according to 
$$P(t) = 200\ln(1+0.5 t) + 50 $$
where $t$ is time in months.

A) What is the initial population at $t=0$?
B) Find the instantaneous growth rate of the population at $t=6$. 
<!-- C) Is the population increasing or decreasing after six months? -->

<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#solutions-1 data-menu-title="Solutions"}

[Solutions]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
A) 

$$
\begin{align}
5 + \ln(3x) &= 7 \\
\ln(3x) &= 2 \\
3x &= e^2 \\
x & = \frac{e^2}{3} \\
\end{align}
$$
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
B) 

$$
\begin{align}
e^{5x-0.2} &= 10 \\
\ln(e^{5x-0.2}) &= \ln(10) \\
5x-0.2 &= \ln(10) \\
5x &= \ln(10) + 0.2 \\
x &= \frac{\ln(10) + 0.2}{5}
\end{align}
$$
:::
::::

2. 

To take the derivative of $f(x) = x\ln(x)$ we can use the product rule: $(fg)' = f'g + fg'$. 
Using this we have that

$$
f'(x) = 1\ln(x) + x\frac{1}{x} = \ln(x) + 1. 
$$

<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#solutions-2 data-menu-title="Solutions" .smaller}

[Solutions]{.slide-title}

<hr>

3) The popuplation $P(t)$ of an invasive plant species in a wetland (in thousands of individuals) grows according to 
$P(t) = 200\ln(1+0.5 t) + 50$
where $t$ is time in months.

**1. Initial population at $t = 0$**

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(0) &= 200 \, \ln(1 + 0.5 \cdot 0) + 50 \\
      &= 200 \, \ln(1) + 50 \\
      &= 0 + 50 \\
      &= 50
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial population is 50,000 individuals.

**2. Instantaneous growth rate at $t = 6$ months**

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
The derivative of $P(t)$ is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
P'(t) &= \frac{d}{dt} \big[200 \, \ln(1 + 0.5 t) + 50 \big] \\
      &= 200 \cdot \frac{1}{1 + 0.5 t} \cdot 0.5 \\
      &= \frac{100}{1 + 0.5 t}
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
At $t = 6$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
P'(6) &= \frac{100}{1 + 0.5 \cdot 6} \\
       &= \frac{100}{1 + 3} \\
       &= \frac{100}{4} \\
       &= 25
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

::::


The population is growing at 25,000 individuals per month at $t = 6$.

<!-- **3. Is growth slowing down or speeding up?**

$P'(t) = \frac{100}{1 + 0.5 t}$  

- As $t$ increases, $P'(t)$ **decreases**.  
- Therefore, the population growth is **slowing down over time**. -->

## {#rect data-menu-title="Riemann Sum"}

[Riemann sums]{.slide-title}

<hr>
1. Start at one end of the interval $[a,b]$

2. Evaluate the function at $f(a)$.

3. Step away from $a$ by some small amount called $\Delta x$.

4. Multiply $f(a)\Delta x$ to get the the area of the first rectangle.

5. Repeat the same steps above, now starting with $\Delta x$ as the bottom left corner of the next rectangle. Repeat until you cover the area with rectangles of width $\Delta x$. 

6. Sum up the area of all $k$ rectangles.

<span style="color:red">
$$
R(f(x), \Delta x)= \underbrace{f(x_1)\Delta x+f(x_2)\Delta x+...f(x_k)\Delta x}_{\text{Sum of area of rectangles with width $\Delta(x)$} }
$$
</span>

This is called a **Riemann Sum**.

<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#exp-reimman data-menu-title="Riemann Sum"}

[Finer and finer Riemann sums]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- What if we try to make $\Delta x$ (the width of the rectangles) really small? So we let $\Delta x \to 0$. This will make the number of rectangles under the curve go to infinity.

- Our estimation of the area will get better and better with more rectangles.

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/riemann.gif){fig-align="center" width="90%"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
<br>

:::{.fragment .fade-in}
Take the area calculation we did before, but let $\Delta x \to 0$
<span style="color:red">
$$
\large
\begin{align}
\text{True Area} &= \lim_{\Delta x \to 0}R(f(x),\Delta x) \\
                  &= \int^b_af(x)dx
\end{align}
$$
</span>

We formally call this <span style="color:red">**the integral of $f(x)$ from $a$ to $b$ with respect to $x$**</span>.
:::
:::

::::

<hr>

- Taking infinite sums is impossible by hand

<br>

<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#fundamental data-menu-title="Fundamental Theorem of Calculus"}

[Fundamental Theorem of Calculus]{.slide-title}

<hr>

If $f(x)$ is continuous over an interval $[a,b]$, and the function $F(x)$ is defined by:

$$
\large
F(x)=\int^x_af(t)dt
$$

then $F'(x)=f(x)$ over $[a,b]$.

. . .

<br>

This can be somewhat confusing. What it means intuitively is

<div class="page-center">
<span style="color:red">
*to find the integral of $\int f(t) dt$ we need to find a function $F(x)$ whose derivative is $f(x)$.*
</span>
</div>

. . .


If we integrate a derivative, we should get the same function back as the original vice-versa

$$
\begin{align}
\int f'(x)&=f(x)+C &\text{Integration is the inverse of differentiation}
\end{align}
$$

:::{.fragment .fade-in}
$$
\begin{align}
\frac{d}{dx}\left[\int f(x)dx\right]&=f(x) &\text{Differentiation is the inverse of integration}
\end{align}
$$
:::

<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#c data-menu-title="Constants of Integration"}

[Where did that $C$ come from?]{.slide-title}

<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

**Example** 

:::{.fragment .fade-in}
- Start with $f(x) = x^2-4x+1$

- Then $f'(x) = 2x-4$
:::

:::{.fragment .fade-in}
To find $\int 2x-4$ we need to find a function whose derivative is $2x-4$. What could it be?
:::

:::{.fragment .fade-in}
- If we integrate, we'll have $\int 2x-4 = x^2-4x+C$. 

- There is no way of knowing what the $C$ should be without additional information

- $C$ is the $x$-intercept and we would have we have to solve for it with an initial value problem.
:::

:::
:::{.column width="50%"}
```{r,out.width="75%"}
knitr::include_graphics("images/c.png")
```
:::

## {#notation data-menu-title="Notation"}

[Notation]{.slide-title}

<hr>

When you take an integral, the function in it can be in terms of any variable. This is just notation and it does not affect the result of the integration:

$$\int f(x) dx = \int f(t) dt = \int f(u) du.$$

<!----------------------------------------------------->

:::

## {#sum-diff data-menu-title="Rules of Integration"}

[Integration rules (1)]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::{.center-text}
**Sum and Difference Rules**
:::

The integral of a sum is equal to the sum of the integrals:

$$
\int[f(x)+g(x)]dx=\int f(x)dx+\int g(x)dx
$$

The integral of the difference is equal to the difference of the integrals: 

$$\int[f(x)-g(x)]dx=\int f(x)dx-\int g(x)dx $$
<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#constant-blank data-menu-title="Rules of Integration"}

[Integration rules (2)]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::{.center-text}
**Constant Rule**
:::
<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#constant data-menu-title="Rules of Integration"}

[Integration rules (2)]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::{.center-text}
**Constant Rule**
:::

When a function is mulitplied by a constant, the constant can be taken out to multiply the integral:

$$
\int cf(x)dx=c\int f(x)dx
$$
<!----------------------------------------------------->

:::

## {#power data-menu-title="Rules of Integration"}

[Integration rules (3)]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::{.center-text}
**Power Rule**
:::

$$
\int x^ndx=\frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1}+C \text{, n}\ne -1
$$

## {#ivp-ex-blank  data-menu-title="Initial Value Problem"}

[Example]{.slide-title}

<hr>

✏️ [The marginal cost of producing $x$ units of a product is:]{style="color:green;"}

[
$$
\frac{dC}{dx}=25-0.02x
$$
]{style="color:green;"}

[Where $C$ is the cost (in dollars), and $x$ is the number of units produced. Given that producing 2 units of product costs \$10, what is the complete cost equation?]{style="color:green;"}

<!----------------------------------------------------->

## {#ivp-ex  data-menu-title="Initial Value Problem" .smaller}

[Example]{.slide-title}

<hr>

✏️ [The marginal cost of producing $x$ units of a product is:]{style="color:green;"}

[
$$
\frac{dC}{dx}=25-0.02x
$$
]{style="color:green;"}

[Where $C$ is the cost (in dollars), and $x$ is the number of units produced. Given that producing 2 units of product costs \$10, what is the complete cost equation?]{style="color:green;"}

We can integrate to find the original cost function $C$:

$$C(x) = \int \frac{dC}{dx} dx = \int 25-0.02x.$$

Then: 
$$
\begin{align}
\int 25-0.02x =&25x-\frac{.02x^2}{2}+D & \text{Solve with Power Rule}\\
10&=25(2)-\frac{0.02(2)^2}{2}+D  &\text{ Sub in $x=2$}\\
-39.96&=D\\
C(x)&=25x-\frac{0.2x^2}{2}-39.96
\end{align}
$$

## {#area-ex2 data-menu-title="Area between curves"}

[Example]{.slide-title}

<hr>

We need to compute

$$\int^1_0 \sqrt{x} - \int^1_0 x^2.$$

Compute each piece carfully:

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
$$
\small
\begin{align}
\int^1_0 \sqrt{x} &=\frac{2}{3}x^\frac{3}{2} \Big|_0^1\\
                  &= \frac{2}{3}(1)^{\frac{3}{2}}-\frac{2}{3}(0)^{\frac{3}{2}} \\
                  &= \frac{2}{3}.
\end{align}
$$
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
$$
\small
\begin{align}
\int^1_0 x^2 &=\frac{1}{3}x^3\Big|_0^1 \\
            &= \frac{1}{3}(1)^3-\frac{1}{3}(0)^3 \\
            &= \frac{1}{3}.
\end{align}
$$
:::

::::

Then subtract the upper from the lower:

$$
\small
\frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{1}{3}
$$

## {#ta2-1 data-menu-title="Team Assessment 2 Questions"}

1) Find the integrals of $y$ and $g$ and solve the integral in C. 

$$
\begin{align}
\text{A) }y=\frac{3}{x^2}, y(3)=2&  &\text{B)  }g(t)=3t^5-2t^3+16t-7  &  &\text{C) } \int^4_2\frac{1}{2}x
\end{align}
$$

## {#ta2-A-solution data-menu-title="Team Assessment 2 Questions"}

[Solution (A)]{.slide-title}

We have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int \frac{3}{x^2}\,dx 
&= 3 \int x^{-2}\,dx \\[6pt]
&= 3 \left( \frac{x^{-1}}{-1} \right) + C \\[6pt]
&= -\frac{3}{x} + C
\end{aligned}
$$

With the initial value $y(3)=2$ we obtain

$$
\begin{align}
2 &= y(3) \\
  &= -\frac{3}{3} + C \\
  &= -1 + C \\
3 &= C.
\end{align}
$$

Therefore the solution is
$-\frac{3}{x} +3$. 

## {#ta2-B-solution data-menu-title="Team Assessment 2 Questions"}

[Solution (B)]{.slide-title}

We have that

$$\begin{aligned}
\int \bigl(3t^{5}-2t^{3}+16t-7\bigr)\,dt
&= \int 3t^{5}\,dt - \int 2t^{3}\,dt + \int 16t\,dt - \int 7\,dt \\[6pt]
&= 3\frac{t^{6}}{6} - 2\frac{t^{4}}{4} + 16\frac{t^{2}}{2} - 7t + C \\[6pt]
&= \frac{t^{6}}{2} - \frac{t^{4}}{2} + 8t^{2} - 7t + C
\end{aligned}$$

## {#ta2-C-solution data-menu-title="Team Assessment 2 Questions"}

[Solution (C)]{.slide-title}

We get that

$$\begin{aligned}
\int_{2}^{4} \frac{1}{2}x\,dx 
&= \frac{1}{2}\int_{2}^{4} x\,dx \\[6pt]
&= \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{2}^{4} \\[6pt]
&= \frac{1}{4}\bigl(4^{2}-2^{2}\bigr) \\[6pt]
&= \frac{1}{4}(16-4) \\[6pt]
&= 3
\end{aligned}$$

## {#ta2-2 data-menu-title="Team Assessment 2 Questions"}

2) A model for the rate of change in ozone concentrations over time between 1962-1984 is given by $\frac{dC}{dt}=2t+20$, where $C$ is the ozone concentration (ppm) and $t$ is the elapsed time in years since 1962. Given that in 1964 the ozone concentration was 30 ppm, what was the ozone concentration in 1982?

## {#ta2-D-solution data-menu-title="Team Assessment 2 Questions" .smaller}

[Solution]{.slide-title}

Given:  
$$\frac{dC}{dt} = 2t + 20$$

Integrate:  
$$\int dC = \int (2t + 20)\,dt$$  

$$C(t) = t^{2} + 20t + D$$  

Initial condition:  
$$C(2)=30 \ \  \text{(since 1964 is 2 years after 1962)}$$  

$$30 = 2^{2} + 20\cdot 2 + D$$  

$$D = 30 - 44 = -14$$  

Thus:  
$$C(t) = t^{2} + 20t - 14$$  

Evaluate at $t=20$ (1982):  

$$C(20) = 20^{2} + 20\cdot 20 - 14$$  

$$= 400 + 400 - 14$$  

$$= 786 \text{ ppm}$$
